abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Third Xinjiang Highway
            Project for China were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            during project implementation, Xinjiang Communications
            Department (XCD) increased its funding for road maintenance,
            and introduced some improvement in management. The condition
            of Xinjiang's road network at the end of the project
            showed to be significant better than at the start. However,
            during the same period, XCD, with its own funds, carried out
            a substantial program of improvements of the Xinjiang's
            road network, which likely had a significant impact on the
            condition of the network. XCD sought to maximize the impact
            of the training by requiring trainees to evaluate the
            various training sessions and by disseminating inside the
            agency the knowledge received by the trainees. Past
            experience has shown that a good training mix should include
            both domestic and foreign training. Designers generally pay
            less attention to the design of local roads, limiting their
            efforts to a sketchy design much less accurate than the one
            of the expressway, thinking these local roads are less
            important. Experience showed that could lead to major
            problems at implementation stage, particularly for the roads
            in difficult topography and geology. A recurrent problem in
            the four-lane sections of Kuitun-Sailimuhu Highway (KSH)
            road is the dangerous crossing at at-grade intersections.

TF026427-PHRD-CHINA: THIRD XINJIANG
            HIGHWAY PROJECT (RECIPIENT-EXECUTED),TF038822-CHINA - PREPARATION O FJAIANGXI
            II, II AND INNER MONGOLIA,TF026642-PHRD-CHINA: THIRD XINJIANG

5086712.majtheme: Public sector governance,Rural development,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Xinjiang Highway project aims
            to improve transport infrastructure, and sector governance
            in support of socioeconomic development in Xinjiang Uygur
            Autonomous Region, in Western China. To meet its development
            objective, the components will: 1) include the construction
            of a four lane expressway, and additional two lanes in the
            Kuitun-SailimuHu Highway, as well as upgrading the existing
            two lane roads to Class 1 (and/or Class 2) standard,
            combining new, and existing alignments. An eighty percent of
            the KuiSai highway will use the existing alignment, while
            new alignments will mostly serve as bypasses to urbanized
            areas in Wusu, and Jinghe; 2) connect primary local roads,
            and townships to the provincial, and national highway
            system, to ensure access to rural areas, and poor counties.
            The component will entail a four-year rehabilitation
            program, implemented under a programmatic approach; and, 3)
            strengthen institutional capacity, by providing training
            assistance, and specialized equipment, to address sector
            issues, key in preparing future sector reforms. This
            includes traffic safety, highway toll management, road
            management and maintenance, and transport facilitation.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Third Xinjiang Highway Project :
            indigenous peoples plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This Indigenous Peoples Plan (IPP),
            based on social assessments, and direct field observations,
            identifies in Xinjiang Province a highly diversified
            population, both in the number of minorities, as in the
            varying patterns of population dispersion. Distinctive
            characteristics identify language; culture; economic
            activities and reliance on subsistence modes of production;
            the use of customary and cultural institutions; attachment
            to ancestral territory, or natural resources, i.e., long
            established, traditional herd migration routes. Following
            consultations, concerns included roadway and traffic safety,
            access for pedestrians and non-motorized traffic, protection
            of ecologically fragile pastures, and protection of cultural
            heritage sites. Design, and implementation arrangements will
            take these concerns into consideration. The IPP took also
            into consideration China's legal framework,
            particularly the legislation on minority nationality
            regions, administrative regulation in minority nationality
            townships, and the law on villager committee organization.
            Issues and measures relating to land acquisition, and lost
            assets; environmental protection; highway safety; and,
            livestock access are defined in the institutional, and
            project arrangements, based on consultations with
            minorities, while monitoring and grievance mechanisms will
            be contained in the environmental assessment, and
            resettlement action plan.

1793564.trustfund:
TF040722-CHINA: THIRD XINJIANG HIGHWAY PROJECT,TF026427-PHRD-CHINA: THIRD XINJIANG
            HIGHWAY PROJECT (RECIPIENT-EXECUTED),TF026642-PHRD-CHINA: THIRD XINJIANG

            II, II AND INNER MONGOLIA
1793564.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Rural development,Public sector governance

repnme.cdata!:
China - Third Xinjiang Highway Project :
            environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
One of the main components of the Third
            Highway Project is the Kuitun-Sailimu Hu Highway, an
            important section of the National Trunk Highway System
            (NTHS) and the remaining gap on the 1430 km stretch of the
            National Highway 312 in Xinjiang. It will undergo major
            construction, alignment, and upgrading. During the designing
            period, the design of sewage treatment in stations and
            service areas should guarantee the life sewage and
            industrial wastewater within disposal standard. The highway
            should avoid running through residential districts in
            cities/towns, and the alignment should be away from schools
            and hospitals. The highway should occupy as little
            farmlands, grasslands, and woods as possible. Trees removed
            will be replanted. During construction, sewage from the
            construction camps can be led into available drainage
            network. Wastewater with oil should be collected and stored
            in a pond for eventual drying up. Oil or chemical pollutants
            and waste materials will be disposed of in accordance with
            regulations. Water should be sprayed to avoid dust. The new
            construction and traffic access roads should be paved with
            asphalt. Noise impacts will be reduced by locating
            constructions far away from protected areas. No borrow pits
            are allowed in the wind gap and farmlands. Sites should be
            restored after construction. During operation, enclosing
            walls will be built to reduce noise levels. Live sewage
            water can be used for landscaping purpose following treatment.

environmental impact assessment - addendum
